column5: refers to taking available non-ontological resources2 (e.g., databases, controlled vocabularies, etc.) for the development of ontologies. Non-Ontological Resource Reuse is defined in [80] as the process of choosing the most suitable non-ontological resources for the development of ontologies.
column7: To choose the most suitable non ontological resources for building ontologies.

column5: the process of retrieving and transforming an existing non ontological resource (data bases, controlled vocabularies, etc.) into an ontology.

is defined as the process of using available ontological resources (ontologies, modules, statements, or ontology design patterns) in the solution of different problems (e.g., the development of different ontology-based applications, the activity of ontology aligning (as background knowledge), etc.). We distinguish between: ontology reuse, ontology module reuse, ontology statement reuse, and ontology design pattern reuse
the process of using ontologies in the solution of different problems
the process of using ontology modules in the solution of different problems
column13: Activities (1) Ontology Search; (2) Ontology Modularization; (3) Ontology Module Assessment; (4) Ontology Module Selection; (5) Ontology Module Integration

column5: the process of using ontology statements in the solution of different problems
General or Common Ontology Reuse refers to the process of using general or common ontologies in the solution of different problems.
Domain Ontology Reuse refers to the process of using domain ontologies in the solution of different problems.
the process of retrieving and transforming a conceptual model of an existing and implemented ontology into a new, more correct and more complete conceptual model which is reimlemented.
